title.value: Swarm-SLAM: Sparse Decentralized Collaborative Simultaneous Localization and Mapping Framework for Multi-Robot Systems
title.justification: The title is stated at the beginning of the paper and matches the content described.
title.quote: Swarm-SLAM: Sparse Decentralized Collaborative Simultaneous Localization and Mapping Framework for Multi-Robot Systems

extractions.description: The paper introduces Swarm-SLAM, a decentralized, flexible, and scalable Collaborative Simultaneous Localization And Mapping (C-SLAM) system designed for multi-robot systems. The system supports various sensors and includes a novel inter-robot loop closure prioritization technique to enhance communication efficiency and reduce resource usage.

type.justification: The paper evaluates the Swarm-SLAM system on multiple datasets and conducts real-world experiments, indicating it is an empirical study.
type.quote: We evaluated our ROS 2 implementation on five different datasets, and in a real-world experiment with three robots communicating through an ad-hoc network.

name.justification: The study focuses on a framework for multi-robot systems and Collaborative SLAM, which are central topics in robotics.
name.quote: Collaborative Simultaneous Localization And Mapping (C-SLAM) is a vital component for successful multi-robot operations in environments without an external positioning system.

name.justification: The paper focuses on Collaborative SLAM, which is a combination of perception and mapping techniques used in multi-robot systems.
name.quote: In this paper, we introduce Swarm-SLAM, an open-source C-SLAM system that is designed to be scalable, flexible, decentralized, and sparse, which are all key properties in swarm robotics.

name.justification: The model is mentioned as being used for pose graph optimization in Swarm-SLAM.
name.quote: Swarm-SLAM performs the pose graph optimization using the Graduated Non-Convexity [15] solver, with the robust Truncated Least Square loss.

name.justification: The model is mentioned in the context of being an alternative method for optimization in C-SLAM systems.
name.quote: In Table II, we present the estimates computed in the back-end on all the sequences for which GPS latitude and longitude data is available as ground truth. Using our same front-end, we compared our GNC-based decentralized back-end against two state-of-the-art distributed approaches: the Distributed Gauss-Seidel (DGS) pose graph optimization [10] combined with Pairwise Consistency Maximization (PCM) for outlier rejection as used in [7]

name.justification: The model is mentioned as a comparison for distributed optimization techniques in C-SLAM.
name.quote: In Table II, we present the estimates computed in the back-end on all the sequences for which GPS latitude and longitude data is available as ground truth. Using our same front-end, we compared our GNC-based decentralized back-end against two state-of-the-art distributed approaches...and a distributed implementation of Graduated Non-Convexity (D-GNC) [16] based on the RCBD solver.

name.justification: The paper specifically mentions KITTI 00 as one of the datasets used for evaluation.
name.quote: First, we tested on the widely known autonomous driving KITTI 00 stereo sequence [27] which we split into two parts to simulate a two-robots exploration.

name.justification: The paper specifically mentions KITTI-360 09 as one of the datasets used for evaluation.
name.quote: Second, we split the very large (âˆ¼10km) KITTI360 09 lidar sequence [28] into 5 parts that contain a large number of loop closures, making it particularly well suited for inter-robot loop closure detection analysis.

name.justification: The paper specifically mentions the GrAco dataset as one of the used datasets.
name.quote: Third, we experimented on the first three overlapping lidar sequences of the very recent GrAco dataset [29] acquired with custom ground robots on a college campus.

name.justification: The M2DGR dataset is mentioned as an experimental dataset to test the proposed system.
name.quote: Fourth, we evaluate our system on the three lidar Gate sequences of the M2DGR dataset [30].

name.justification: The S3E dataset is mentioned as an experimental dataset to test the proposed system.
name.quote: Fifth, we tested on three sequences of the recent C-SLAM-focused S3E dataset [31].

name.justification: The ROS 2 framework is mentioned as the implementation framework for the proposed system.
name.quote: We evaluated our ROS 2 implementation on five different datasets, and in a real-world experiment with three robots communicating through an ad-hoc network.
